So what that means is in order to trade volatility from a pure perspective, you don't want to trade it via iron condors or via defined risk strategies because then you're buying the exact thing you're saying is overpriced. But then we can also have if something is cash settled or settled with the underlying. So SPX is an example of a European style option where it can only be exercised at expiration and it's cash settled. There's no shares that move. So if, for example, I sell an option and it's in the money and it's exercised, it just settles to cash. There's no underlying that moves around. Good question though. All right, gang.
